intro: Marcgravia serrae, commonly known as the serrated mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on the branches of trees in the Neotropical region. It has small, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, and its flowers are typically white or pale green, arranged in clusters. The plant produces small, fleshy fruits that are dispersed by birds, contributing to its propagation. Its parasitic nature allows it to obtain water and nutrients from its host, while still performing photosynthesis. Marcgravia serrae plays a role in the ecological dynamics of its habitat, supporting various insect and bird species.
